Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They identify a malfunctioning pool filtration system that could endanger swimmers’ safety if not repaired immediately.
Story: I was sitting in the lifeguard office, scrolling through my phone, when I noticed a text from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I hadn’t checked in with my parents all week, and guilt pricked at me. I knew they worried if I went too long without a message. I started typing a reply, but just then, I heard the pool’s filtration system sputter and groan. I went to check and realized the filter wasn’t working—if I didn’t fix it right away, the water could become unsafe for swimmers. My supervisor always emphasized that equipment maintenance was a top priority, and I could already picture the disappointed faces of the morning swim team if the pool had to close. My phone buzzed again in my hand, another message from Mom. I stood there, torn, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me: the son who should call home, and the lifeguard responsible for everyone’s safety.
